message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Scaling Dialogue for Democracy: Can Automated Deliberation Create More Deliberative Voters?
Paper Abstract: The theory and practice of what has come to be called “deliberative democracy” have been revived for the modern era with a focus on deliberative microcosms selected through random sampling or “sortition.” But might it be possible to spread some of the benefits of deliberation beyond mini-publics to the broader society? Can technology assist with scaling an organized deliberative process? In particular, would those who experience such a process become more deliberative voters? Would their considered judgments from deliberation influence their voting? We draw on a larger than usual experiment with public deliberation and a one-year follow-up in the mid-term U.S. elections to suggest answers to these questions. It has implications for whether spreading an organized deliberative process could, in theory, be used to create more deliberative elections.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Deliberative democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_democracy"},{"title":"Deliberative opinion poll - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_opinion_poll"},{"title":"James S. Fishkin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_S._Fishkin"},{"title":"Deliberative referendum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_referendum"},{"title":"Radical democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radical_democracy"},{"title":"Epistemic democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_democracy"},{"title":"V-Dem Democracy Indices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democracy_indices_(V-Dem)"},{"title":"Peoples' Equality and Democracy Party - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peoples'_Equality_and_Democracy_Party"},{"title":"Robert Cavalier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Cavalier"},{"title":"Online deliberation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_deliberation"}]

Here are the search results for "deliberative democracy":

## Overview

Deliberative democracy is a form of democracy in which deliberation is central to decision-making.(no content)For a democratic decision to be legitimate, it must be preceded by authentic deliberation, not merely the aggregation of preferences that occurs in voting.

## Key Characteristics

Deliberative democracy seeks quality over quantity by limiting decision-makers to a smaller but more representative sample of the population that is given the time and resources to focus on one issue.(no content)It often adopts elements of both consensus decision-making and majority rule.(no content)Authentic deliberation is deliberation among decision-makers that is free from distortions of unequal political power, such as power a decision-maker obtains through economic wealth or the support of interest groups.

## Theoretical Foundations

The roots of deliberative democracy can be traced back to Aristotle and his notion of politics; however, the German philosopher Jürgen Habermas' work on communicative rationality and the public sphere is often identified as a major work in this area.(no content)Joseph M. Bessette has been credited with coining the term in his 1980 work Deliberative Democracy: The Majority Principle in Republican Government.

## Forms and Applications

Deliberative democracy has a long history of practice and theory traced back to ancient times, with an increase in academic attention in the 1990s, and growing implementations since 2010. Practical implementations include deliberative opinion polls and citizen assemblies designed to measure and influence public opinion through structured deliberation processes.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "civic engagement deliberation". Here's what I found:

## Overview

Civic engagement is any individual or group activity addressing issues of public concern, including communities working together or individuals working alone in both political and non-political actions to protect public values or make a change in a community.(no content)The goal of civic engagement is to address public concerns and promote the quality of the community.

## Deliberation in Civic Engagement

A key component of civic engagement assemblies is their deliberative nature, which allows members to reflect on their values and weigh new information in dialogue with subject-matter experts and their peers.(no content)Deliberative democracy is a form of democracy in which deliberation is central to decision-making.(no content)Deliberative democracy seeks quality over quantity by limiting decision-makers to a smaller but more representative sample of the population that is given the time and resources to focus on one issue.

## Key Forms and Approaches

Civil discourse is the practice of deliberating about matters of public concern with others in a way that seeks to expand knowledge and promote understanding.(no content)Civic engagement can take many forms—from individual volunteerism, community engagement efforts, organizational involvement, and electoral participation.

The research shows that deliberation is increasingly recognized as essential to meaningful civic engagement, particularly through mechanisms like citizens' assemblies and deliberation initiatives that bring diverse groups together for informed discussion on public issues.

I've completed the web search for "civic engagement deliberation". Here's what I found:

## Overview

Civic engagement is any individual or group activity addressing issues of public concern, including communities working together or individuals working alone in both political and non-political actions to protect public values or make a change in a community.(no content)The goal of civic engagement is to address public concerns and promote the quality of the community.

## Deliberation in Civic Engagement

A key component of civic engagement assemblies is their deliberative nature, which allows members to reflect on their values and weigh new information in dialogue with subject-matter experts and their peers.(no content)Deliberative democracy is a form of democracy in which deliberation is central to decision-making.(no content)Deliberative democracy seeks quality over quantity by limiting decision-makers to a smaller but more representative sample of the population that is given the time and resources to focus on one issue.

## Key Forms and Approaches

Civil discourse is the practice of deliberating about matters of public concern with others in a way that seeks to expand knowledge and promote understanding.(no content)Civic engagement can take many forms—from individual volunteerism, community engagement efforts, organizational involvement, and electoral participation.

The research shows that deliberation is increasingly recognized as essential to meaningful civic engagement, particularly through mechanisms like citizens' assemblies and deliberation initiatives that bring diverse groups together for informed discussion on public issues.

Links: [{"title":"Elections in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"2024 United States presidential election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election"},{"title":"United States presidential election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election"},{"title":"2020 United States presidential election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election"},{"title":"Voter turnout in United States presidential elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voter_turnout_in_United_States_presidential_elections"},{"title":"2020 United States elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_elections"},{"title":"2022 United States elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_United_States_elections"},{"title":"2026 United States elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2026_United_States_elections"},{"title":"United States Electoral College - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College"},{"title":"2025 United States state legislative elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_United_States_state_legislative_elections"}]

I've performed the web search for "United States elections voting" and found comprehensive information about U.S. elections. Here's an overview of the key results:

## U.S. Elections and Voting System

**Election Structure:**
The United States uses indirect elections for its president through the Electoral College, and the system is highly decentralized like other elections in the United States.(no content)The candidate who receives an absolute majority of electoral votes (at least 270 out of 538) is then elected to that office.

**Voting Methods:**
The most common voting method is the first-past-the-post system, where the highest-polling candidate wins the election. Under this system, a candidate who achieves a plurality of vote wins.(no content)Since 2002, several cities have adopted instant-runoff voting where voters rank the candidates in order of preference rather than voting for a single candidate.

**Federal and State Elections:**
All members of the federal legislature, the Congress, are directly elected by the people of each state.(no content)There are many elected offices at state level, each state having at least an elective governor and legislature. General elections for state and local offices are held at the discretion of the individual state and local governments.

**Voting Options:**
Voters unable or unwilling to vote at polling stations on Election Day may vote via absentee ballots, depending on state law.(no content)In Colorado, Hawaii, Oregon, Utah and Washington state, all ballots are delivered through the mail.

The search results cover recent elections including the 2020, 2022, 2024, and upcoming 2026 elections across the United States.

Web search results for query: "sortition random sampling"

Links: [{"title":"Sortition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sortition"},{"title":"Sampling (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_sampling"},{"title":"Randomization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomization"},{"title":"Stratified randomization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stratified_randomization"},{"title":"Applications of randomness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_randomness"},{"title":"Simple random sample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_random_sample"},{"title":"Talk:Sortition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Sortition"},{"title":"Algorand - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorand"},{"title":"Funding by lottery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Funding-by-lottery"},{"title":"Citizens' assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_assembly"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about sortition and random sampling:

## Sortition

Sortition is the selection of public officials or jurors at random, by lottery, in order to obtain a representative sample.(no content)In ancient Athenian democracy, sortition was the traditional and primary method for appointing political officials.(no content)Sortition (also called allotment) is today used in the selection of jurors in Anglo-Saxon legal systems like the UK and United States.(no content)Claudia Chwalisz has advocated for using citizens' assemblies selected by sortition to inform policymaking on an ongoing basis.

## Random Sampling

In statistics, sampling is the selection of a subset of individuals from within a statistical population to estimate characteristics of the whole population, with the subset meant to reflect the whole population.(no content)A random sample of individuals from a population refers to a sample where every individual has a known probability of being sampled.(no content)A simple random sample is a subset of individuals chosen from a larger set in which a subset of individuals are chosen randomly, all with the same probability.

## Connection Between Them

The two concepts are closely related: sortition uses random selection methodology to achieve fair representation, while random sampling is the statistical technique underlying that random selection process.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "experiment design social science"

Links: [{"title":"Social experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_experiment"},{"title":"Design of experiments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_of_experiments"},{"title":"Quasi-experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasi-experiment"},{"title":"Category:Experimental social sciences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Experimental_social_sciences"},{"title":"Field experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_experiment"},{"title":"Experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experiment"},{"title":"Experimental psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_psychology"},{"title":"Experimental political science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_political_science"},{"title":"Natural experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_experiment"},{"title":"Between-group design experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Between-group_design_experiment"}]

I've completed the web search for "experiment design social science." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A social experiment is a method of psychological or sociological research that observes people's reactions to certain situations or events.

## Key Principles

In disciplines like psychology and political science, a 'true experiment' is a method of social research in which the independent variable is manipulated by the experimenter and the dependent variable is measured. The signifying characteristic of a true experiment is that it randomly allocates the subjects to neutralize experimenter bias and controls for all confounding factors.

## Types of Experimental Designs

**Field Experiments:** Field experiments are increasingly used in the social sciences to study the effects of policy-related interventions in domains such as health, education, crime, social welfare, and politics.

**Quasi-Experimental Design:** A quasi-experiment is a research design used to estimate the causal impact of an intervention. Quasi-experiments share similarities with experiments and randomized controlled trials, but specifically lack random assignment to treatment or control.

**Between-Group Design:** A between-group design is an experiment that has two or more groups of subjects each being tested by a different testing factor simultaneously. The simplest form has a treatment group that receives special treatment and a control group that receives no variable treatment and is used as a reference.

## Important Considerations

Internal validity refers to the extent to which a set of research findings provides compelling information about causality. High internal validity implies that the experimental design excludes extraneous influences, such that one can confidently conclude that variations in the independent variable caused observed changes in the dependent variable.

I've completed the web search for "experiment design social science." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A social experiment is a method of psychological or sociological research that observes people's reactions to certain situations or events.

## Key Principles

In disciplines like psychology and political science, a 'true experiment' is a method of social research in which the independent variable is manipulated by the experimenter and the dependent variable is measured. The signifying characteristic of a true experiment is that it randomly allocates the subjects to neutralize experimenter bias and controls for all confounding factors.

## Types of Experimental Designs

**Field Experiments:** Field experiments are increasingly used in the social sciences to study the effects of policy-related interventions in domains such as health, education, crime, social welfare, and politics.

**Quasi-Experimental Design:** A quasi-experiment is a research design used to estimate the causal impact of an intervention. Quasi-experiments share similarities with experiments and randomized controlled trials, but specifically lack random assignment to treatment or control.

**Between-Group Design:** A between-group design is an experiment that has two or more groups of subjects each being tested by a different testing factor simultaneously. The simplest form has a treatment group that receives special treatment and a control group that receives no variable treatment and is used as a reference.

## Important Considerations

Internal validity refers to the extent to which a set of research findings provides compelling information about causality. High internal validity implies that the experimental design excludes extraneous influences, such that one can confidently conclude that variations in the independent variable caused observed changes in the dependent variable.

I've completed the web search for "voter behavior decision making." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Voter Behavior and Decision Making

Voting behavior refers to how people decide how to vote, and this decision is shaped by a complex interplay between an individual voter's attitudes as well as social factors.

## Key Factors Influencing Voting Decisions

Voter attitudes include characteristics such as ideological predisposition, party identity, degree of satisfaction with the existing government, public policy leanings, and feelings about a candidate's personality traits. Additionally, social factors include race, religion and degree of religiosity, social and economic class, educational level, regional characteristics, gender and age.

## Nature of Voter Decision-Making

Voter decision-making is not a purely rational endeavor but rather is profoundly influenced by personal and social biases and deeply held beliefs as well as characteristics such as personality, memory, emotions, and other psychological factors.

## Different Types of Elections

In national elections, voters usually vote based on their political ideologies. In local and regional elections, voters tend to vote for those who seem more capable to contribute to their area. Voting behavior for referendums differs slightly, as people vote for or against a clearly defined policy.

## Candidate Evaluation

Voters frequently weigh candidates' personal qualities such as experience, integrity, morals, compassion, competence, and leadership potential.

Links: [{"title":"Deliberative opinion poll - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_opinion_poll"},{"title":"Participatory democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_democracy"},{"title":"Opinion poll - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_poll"},{"title":"Talk:Deliberative opinion poll - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Deliberative_opinion_poll"},{"title":"Deliberative democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discursive_democracy"},{"title":"James S. Fishkin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_S._Fishkin"},{"title":"Category:Types of polling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Types_of_polling"},{"title":"Deliberative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative"},{"title":"Citizens' assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_assembly"},{"title":"Liquid democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquid_democracy"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about deliberative opinion polls:

## Definition and Overview

A deliberative opinion poll, sometimes called a deliberative poll, is a form of opinion poll taken before and after significant deliberation.(no content)Political scientist James S. Fishkin of Stanford University first described the concept in 1988.

## How It Works

The typical deliberative opinion poll takes a random, representative sample of citizens and engages them in deliberation on current issues or proposed policy changes through small-group discussions and conversations with competing experts to create more informed and reflective public opinion.

The process involves several key steps:
- A random, representative sample is first polled on the issue(s), members of the sample are invited to gather to discuss the issue(s) (online or in-person) with carefully balanced briefing materials, and then the sample is again polled on the original questions.

## Key Features

A deliberative poll always has 100 to 200 participants, to ensure a statistically significant sample.(no content)Deliberative polling emphasizes measuring opinion change after receiving new information and discussion rather than finding common areas of agreement or concrete policy proposals.(no content)Unlike traditional public polling, deliberative opinion polls measure what the public believes about issues after being offered information and the ability to discuss them with other voters.

## Real-World Applications

Deliberative polls have been run around the world, including recent experiments to conduct discussions virtually in the United States, Hong Kong, Chile, Canada and Japan.

Fishkin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_S._Fishkin"},{"title":"Category:Types of polling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Types_of_polling"},{"title":"Deliberative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative"},{"title":"Citizens' assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_assembly"},{"title":"Liquid democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquid_democracy"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about deliberative opinion polls:

## Definition and Overview

A deliberative opinion poll, sometimes called a deliberative poll, is a form of opinion poll taken before and after significant deliberation.(no content)Political scientist James S. Fishkin of Stanford University first described the concept in 1988.

## How It Works

The typical deliberative opinion poll takes a random, representative sample of citizens and engages them in deliberation on current issues or proposed policy changes through small-group discussions and conversations with competing experts to create more informed and reflective public opinion.

The process involves several key steps:
- A random, representative sample is first polled on the issue(s), members of the sample are invited to gather to discuss the issue(s) (online or in-person) with carefully balanced briefing materials, and then the sample is again polled on the original questions.

## Key Features

A deliberative poll always has 100 to 200 participants, to ensure a statistically significant sample.(no content)Deliberative polling emphasizes measuring opinion change after receiving new information and discussion rather than finding common areas of agreement or concrete policy proposals.(no content)Unlike traditional public polling, deliberative opinion polls measure what the public believes about issues after being offered information and the ability to discuss them with other voters.

## Real-World Applications

Deliberative polls have been run around the world, including recent experiments to conduct discussions virtually in the United States, Hong Kong, Chile, Canada and Japan.

Web search results for query: "citizen assembly"

Links: [{"title":"Citizens' assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_assembly"},{"title":"Citizens' Assembly (Ireland) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_Assembly_(Ireland)"},{"title":"Citizens' Assembly of Scotland - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_Assembly_of_Scotland"},{"title":"Citizens' Assembly on Electoral Reform (British Columbia) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_Assembly_on_Electoral_Reform_(British_Columbia)"},{"title":"Citizens' Assembly on Electoral Reform (Ontario) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_Assembly_on_Electoral_Reform_(Ontario)"},{"title":"Citizens Convention for Climate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens_Convention_for_Climate"},{"title":"UK Climate Assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UK_Climate_Assembly"},{"title":"Helsinki Citizens' Assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helsinki_Citizens'_Assembly"},{"title":"Athenian democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athenian_democracy"},{"title":"Global Assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Assembly"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about citizen assemblies:

## What is a Citizen Assembly?

A citizens' assembly uses elements of a jury to create public policy. Its members form a representative cross-section of the public, and are provided with time, resources and a broad range of viewpoints to learn deeply about an issue.(no content)Through skilled facilitation, the assembly members weigh trade-offs and work to find common ground on a shared set of recommendations.

## How They Work

By incorporating the views, information and arguments of experts and then asking the participants to engage in collaborative discussion, assemblies aim to enable the participants to educate themselves and produce a vote or result representative of the public interest.(no content)While opinion polls can reveal what the public thinks more quickly and cheaply, citizens' assemblies can reveal "what they would reach after considered reflection."

## Examples

Citizens' assemblies have been used in various jurisdictions:

- British Columbia created a Citizens' Assembly on Electoral Reform to investigate changes to the provincial electoral system, and proposed replacing the province's existing first past the post system with BC-STV, a single transferable vote system.
- Ireland established a citizens' assembly in 2016 to consider several political questions including the Constitution, with topics including abortion, fixed term parliaments, referendums, population ageing, and climate change.
- The UK Climate Assembly was formed in January 2020 whose goal was to issue recommendations for how the UK could satisfy its climate change law.

message_text:
## Summary

I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Scaling Dialogue for Democracy: Can Automated Deliberation Create More Deliberative Voters?" Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - The paper proposes a new approach to scale deliberative processes beyond mini-publics and tests whether automated deliberation can create more deliberative voters.

**Triples Identified and Added (10 total):**

1. **Deliberative democracy** (concept, uses) - The foundational theory the paper builds upon
2. **Sortition** (method, uses) - Random sampling method for selecting deliberative participants
3. **Citizens' assembly** (concept, uses) - Mini-public mechanisms studied to understand scaling benefits
4. **Deliberative opinion poll** (method, uses) - Practical implementation of deliberative democracy
5. **Civic engagement** (concept, uses) - Framework for understanding participation and deliberation
6. **Voting behavior** (concept, uses) - Focus area for measuring deliberation effects
7. **Field experiment** (method, uses) - Research methodology employed in the study
8. **Elections in the United States** (task, uses) - Context for testing effects on voter behavior
9. **Scaling deliberation for broader society** (concept, proposes) - Key innovation proposed by the paper
10. **Automated deliberation using technology** (method, proposes) - Technology-enabled approach proposed

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed successfully

All Wikipedia URLs are verified and correct, with proper entity types and relevance descriptions. The paper has at least 1 "uses" relation (required for all papers) and 2 "proposes" relations (required for contribution papers).

Sources:
- [Deliberative democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_democracy)
- [Sortition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sortition)
- [Citizens' assembly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_assembly)
- [Deliberative opinion poll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_opinion_poll)
- [Civic engagement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_engagement)
- [Voting behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voting_behavior)
- [Field experiment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_experiment)
- [Elections in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_the_United_States)
- [Online deliberation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_deliberation)
